newsitem.title: FRANCE: U.S. denies French report Desert Strike finished.
newsitem.headline: U.S. denies French report Desert Strike finished.

text.p: The United States denied on Thursday a French statement that Secretary of State Warren Christopher had assured French leaders the U.S. "Desert Strike" cruise missile operation against Iraq was over.
A senior State Department official told reporters after double-checking with Christopher: "The Secretary of State did not say in the meetings today that Desert Strike is over."

After Christopher met President Jacques Chirac and Foreign Minister Herve de Charette, a French Foreign Ministry statement said he had "confirmed the end of the American 'Desert Strike' operations in Iraq", clearing the way for Paris to rejoin allied air patrols over Iraq from next Monday, but not cross the 32nd parallel to police an extended zone declared by Washington.

State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns told reporters: "American policy and American actions will be based very much on what Saddam Hussein does...We retain the option and the right to use force if necessary."
Asked to explain the apparent discrepancy between the U.S. and French accounts of the talks, the senior official said it might be "linguisitc".

Burns said Christopher had come to explain U.S. actions and urge France to remain in the Gulf War coalition that drove Iraq out of Kuwait in 1991. "Based on the meetings today, the French government has issued this statement. That's good news," he said.
